audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker questioning drug reform and leaving it to the people. Another male speaker responds, stating he does not believe someone should go to jail for smoking a joint and supports decriminalization. He clarifies his stance is more from a health perspective, similar to alcohol, suggesting more freely available with health messages.  The conversation continues referencing a study with interesting work on genetic issues around smoking leading to increased bipolar problems. The speaker suggests carefully considering regulation and what to do if decriminalization is pursued. A simple "Okay" follows before the first speaker asks about law and order. Ambient sounds suggest an indoor environment with general background noise.

The clip opens with a male speaker discussing the government's approach to law and order, mentioning "three strikes" and describing it as something coming from the "south." He elaborates on the prison population, mentioning statistics about illiteracy, alcohol, and drug issues, suggesting rehabilitation in prisons is a good thing. He then discusses the presence of hardcore criminals who, according to him, should be kept away because they commit "90% of our crime."

The audio clip begins with two speakers, a male interviewer and a male interviewee. The interviewer asks if the interviewee would like to see imprisonment rates come down. The interviewee responds in agreement, stating, "we got the second highest in the OECD", and criticizing it as an "appalling record". He continues, emphasizing high recidivism rates, saying they are "astronomically high" and giving an approximate percentage. The overall tone is serious and analytical.

The clip begins with two male speakers discussing crime and the national party, one of them joking about blaming everything on it. He brings up prison rates, leading to a conversational exchange. One male speaker comments, "We've got to be careful," before expressing the sentiment that people are against how sentencing is working. He cites "90,000 bucks to keep somebody in jail" as "a complete waste of money." There's agreement that it's a "dumb thing to do."

The clip begins with a male speaker questioning whether the Labour and National parties are "following the crowd" and noting the speaker's perception that they're not at the forefront of the debate. The speaker then states that there's definitely an issue around "short-term prevention so long as the long-term other issues are addressed," and explains how media attention tends to focus on the number of police on the street, which he considers an important issue, but other longer-term issues also exist. Someone then acknowledges a question from the floor, specifying "Mark Carrie at the front."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing education and student loans, mentioning he has read the policy and found it vague. The speaker speaks in a conversational, inquisitive tone. Following this question, another male speaker replies, confirming the policy intentions. The conversation takes place in a room with the hum of air conditioning in the background, providing a consistent ambient sound.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the possibility of a universal student allowance, stating it would be "the desirable thing" but currently unattainable due to affordability. He then shifts the topic to measures that are more feasible, such as capping fees and suspending interest, with an intention to become more flexible over time. The speaker has a measured tone. The primary sound is the speaker's voice, with no discernible background noises or music present.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing tertiary policy, emphasizing that it's a combination of ensuring access, maintaining the quality of universities, and preventing the best brains from leaving New Zealand. He speaks in an informative tone, explaining the key components. A second male speaker poses a question, wondering if the policies prevent differentiation from the other party. The first speaker begins to respond.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing policy issues in a measured tone. He mentions negotiating with his economics team and compromising, aiming to protect students and maintain interest rates. He highlights the importance of university funding and post-doctoral scholarships. As the interview progresses, the interviewer notes that time is running out and asks for final election predictions in a conversational tone.

The clip features a male speaker who believes that "the greens are doing doing doing well". He thinks they may perform better than last time, but typically "come down off a, off a high". He acknowledges they "could be" and then utters "it's uh, um". His tone is conversational and somewhat speculative. There are no noticeable sounds other than this single speaker.

The clip starts with two male speakers engaging in a conversation. The first male asks if "Mana are just a one-trick, one MP pony". The second man responds, noting that, "they're going to be struggling," and hopes Kelvin Davis gets "Tito Tokaroo," stating he is "a terrific guy and a mate," who would be a good MP. He continues, stating that, "in a small pool he's behind, but nevertheless I think he's got a really good chance." The first male speaker then replies asking if "the Mana could be wiped out." And the second man responds in the affirmative, before the audio clip cuts off.

The clip features two speakers, a male interviewer asking questions, and a second male respondent. The interviewee discusses the political party ACT and possible voter reactions saying "Ipsom voters this time are just saying enough" and suggesting they might not want to vote for banks. He mentions ACT had a very good constituent MP, someone who "got out there and did the business". Then, the conversation shifts to Winston Peters, giving him a "35%" chance of coming back. The interviewee finishes by saying he wouldn't rule Peters out.

The clip starts with a male speaker asking if the "Nationals" will reach 48-50 percent of the vote, similar to their current polling. Another male responds, stating he "hope[s] not." He notes that no party has been above 50 percent since 1951. He indicates that voters focus on individual parties rather than blocks. When asked about his majority, approximately 10,000, he clarifies it was a "byelection." He hopes to maintain his majority but acknowledges by-elections differ from general elections. He says he would like to stay "the same or better." The first male thanks him, and then a few audience members applaud.
